Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Steady rain and frequent lane changes from nearby cars raise the risk of sudden stops
Story: My phone buzzed violently on the dashboard, the screen lighting up with Jamie’s name. I could barely hear his voice over the rain hammering the windshield, but the raw panic in his words cut through the static—something terrible had happened to his family. He needed me, not just as a driver, but as his friend. I wanted to pull over, to listen, to be the shoulder he needed right now. But the wipers barely kept up with the downpour, and the road was a blur of red taillights and weaving cars. My passenger in the back seat was silent, watching the chaos outside. Every instinct screamed at me to focus on the road, to keep everyone safe, to obey the rules that kept us alive in weather like this. But Jamie’s sobs on the other end made my heart ache. I gripped the wheel tighter, torn between the urge to comfort my friend and the responsibility to drive safely. The rain kept falling, and I was caught between two worlds, unable to give either what they needed from me.
